The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed to achieve a wide depth of field. â€¢ Utilize shutter priority mode at 1/250s with ISO 200 fixed to capture moving elements against static lines. â€¢ Experiment with different angles to find the most effective lines that lead to your subject. â€¢ Pay attention to the framing of your shot; make sure leading lines donâ€™t exit the frame. â€¢ Use a wide-angle lens to emphasize leading lines and shapes in your composition. Creative Focus â€¢ Look for natural curves in your environment, such as river bends or winding paths. â€¢ Incorporate man-made elements like fences or roads to create structure in your images. â€¢ Experiment with contrasting shapes and lines to create visual interest. â€¢ Try to include elements that break the lines or shapes to add dynamics to your composition. â€¢ Capture reflections in water or glass to enhance geometric shapes in your photos. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Photograph a pathway or road that leads into the distance, using aperture priority mode at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Find a building with strong geometric lines and capture it from a low angle, using shutter priority mode at 1/500s with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Explore a park and photograph different shapes created by trees, paths, or benches, utilizing aperture priority mode at f/5.6 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Capture the curves of a river or road, ensuring the lines lead towards your subject, using shutter priority mode at 1/250s with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Identify and photograph a fence or wall with leading lines that guide the viewer to a focal point, using aperture priority mode at f/11 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Take a photo of an intersection or crossroads where multiple lines converge, using shutter priority mode at 1/125s with ISO 200 fixed. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Create a series of images focusing on different types of leading lines (curved, straight, diagonal) and present them as a cohesive portfolio. â€¢ Challenge yourself to find and photograph a location using only geometric shapes, avoiding organic lines and curves.
